subject: Revert "Fix member_batch_update function to follow api v2"
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-06-23 08:36:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn/commit/f651a06aeccde3ca99098973348778777ec63db0', 'message': 'Revert "Fix member_batch_update function to follow api v2"

This reverts commit 1cd84b1d54755bdab7f6573d734301850e0b6bd7.

The patch corresponds to a chain of backports to be compatible with the new attribute added to the octavia api for the member_batch_update method. 

Octavia api applied the change on all stable/xxx branches up to ussuri, but it was not applied on stable/train to maintain backwards compatibility.

However the change in ovn-octavia-provider was applied on all stable/xxx branches including stable/train (networking-ovn) so this method expects two parameters while octavia-api (train) only sends one.

Change-Id: Iabdad82e91b3f3fea654c1871a4e04cabf1d1d1a
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2022-06-23 09:09:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn/commit/735779d1277d645617367e0aa5bc7969de0a973d', 'message': 'Revert "Fix member_batch_update function to follow api v2"

This reverts commit 1cd84b1d54755bdab7f6573d734301850e0b6bd7.

The patch corresponds to a chain of backports to be compatible with the
new version of Octavia API, where basically a new attribute was added
to the member_batch_update method.

Octavia API applied the change on all stable/xxx branches up to ussuri,
but it was not applied on stable/train to maintain backwards
compatibility.

However the change in ovn-octavia-provider was applied on all stable/xxx
branches including stable/train (networking-ovn) so this method expects
two parameters while octavia-api (train) only sends one.

Conflicts:
   - octavia/ovn_driver.py
   - tests/units/octavia/test_ovn_driver.py

(manually revert commit 1cd84b1d54755bdab7f6573d734301850e0b6bd7)

Change-Id: Iabdad82e91b3f3fea654c1871a4e04cabf1d1d1a
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2022-06-23 09:25:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn/commit/51e2547051f4d688ec48bfcb9fcb4fbc16cbe2e8', 'message': 'Revert "Fix member_batch_update function to follow api v2"

This reverts commit 1cd84b1d54755bdab7f6573d734301850e0b6bd7.

The patch corresponds to a chain of backports to be compatible with the
new version of Octavia API, where basically a new attribute was added
to the member_batch_update method.

Octavia API applied the change on all stable/xxx branches up to ussuri,
but it was not applied on stable/train to maintain backwards
compatibility.

However the change in ovn-octavia-provider was applied on all stable/xxx
branches including stable/train (networking-ovn) so this method expects
two parameters while octavia-api (train) only sends one.

Conflicts:
   - octavia/ovn_driver.py
   - tests/units/octavia/test_ovn_driver.py

(manually revert commit 1cd84b1d54755bdab7f6573d734301850e0b6bd7)

Change-Id: Iabdad82e91b3f3fea654c1871a4e04cabf1d1d1a
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2022-06-23 14:32:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn/commit/9da9e9985765a5cca32ae962317e6bb8121da914', 'message': 'Revert "Fix member_batch_update function to follow api v2"

This reverts commit 1cd84b1d54755bdab7f6573d734301850e0b6bd7.

The patch corresponds to a chain of backports to be compatible with the
new version of Octavia API, where basically a new attribute was added
to the member_batch_update method [1].

Octavia API applied the change on all stable/xxx branches up to ussuri,
but it was not applied on stable/train to maintain backwards
compatibility [2].

However the change in ovn-octavia-provider was applied on all stable/xxx
branches including stable/train (networking-ovn) so this method expects
two parameters while octavia-api (train) only sends one.

Conflicts:
   - octavia/ovn_driver.py
   - tests/units/octavia/test_ovn_driver.py

Closes-Bug: #1979661

(manually revert commit 1cd84b1d54755bdab7f6573d734301850e0b6bd7)

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/networking-ovn/+/746134
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/octavia/+/688548/

Change-Id: Iabdad82e91b3f3fea654c1871a4e04cabf1d1d1a

commit_message:
Revert "Fix member_batch_update function to follow api v2"

This reverts commit 1cd84b1d54755bdab7f6573d734301850e0b6bd7.

The patch corresponds to a chain of backports to be compatible with the
new version of Octavia API, where basically a new attribute was added
to the member_batch_update method [1].

Octavia API applied the change on all stable/xxx branches up to ussuri,
but it was not applied on stable/train to maintain backwards
compatibility [2].

However the change in ovn-octavia-provider was applied on all stable/xxx
branches including stable/train (networking-ovn) so this method expects
two parameters while octavia-api (train) only sends one.

Conflicts:
   - octavia/ovn_driver.py
   - tests/units/octavia/test_ovn_driver.py

Closes-Bug: #1979661

(manually revert commit 1cd84b1d54755bdab7f6573d734301850e0b6bd7)

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/networking-ovn/+/746134
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/octavia/+/688548/

Change-Id: Iabdad82e91b3f3fea654c1871a4e04cabf1d1d1a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn refs/changes/55/847255/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.ovn_driver.member_batch_update(members)

This is the 4.0 version of the charm and is intended to only
support 4.0. So, trim tests and point gitreview at 4.0 branch.

Change-Id: I423afc319d72a8d64e6f76c02583e066ec64c4a6

Changes to the RBD Driver in Yoga leverage the RBD trash
functionality to enable Cinder users to delete volumes
that are still used in a dependency chain of Cinder volume
clones and in the future snapshots.

This relies on something purging the RBD trash.
In addition to this patch the user needs to enable the
rbd trash purge scheduling functionality. In this way the
Ceph backend will purge RBD images that are no longer used. 

Change-Id: Id8e581893ee4b373b268acc7c59b670985cedc2f
'}, {'number': 8, 'created': '2022-05-02 19:29:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack-plugin-ceph/commit/b03ad0600628b4da76304923b2bad055d066e8d9', 'message': 'Ceph min client version set to Mimic

Changes to the RBD driver leverage the RBD trash functionality to allow
Cinder users to delete snapshots that are still in a dependency chain.

This requires that the RBD trash namespace be emptied.
In addition to this patch, the user must enable the RBD Trash Purge
scheduling feature. In this way, the Ceph backend will delete RBD images
that are no longer in use.

The goal of this patch is to add a variable to set the min cliento to
Mimic, defaulting to True and additional check to avoid old versions >
13.

client version used in a Manila/Glance/Nova/Cinder test job in addition

A new configuration option, CEPH_MIN_ CLIENT _VERSION, has been
introduced to specify a Ceph-minium client version that allows proper
handling when deleting images and snapshots with dependencies, etc. The
default value is null.

Co-Author-By: Sofia Enriquez <lsofia.enriquez@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Id8e581893ee4b373b268acc7c59b670985cedc2f

commit_message:
Ceph set minimum client version

This patch adds a new VAR for when the user wants to set the minimum
client version used in a Manila/Glance/Nova/Cinder test job in addition
to using devstack.

A new configuration option, CEPH_MIN_ CLIENT _VERSION, has been
introduced to specify a Ceph-minium client version that allows proper
handling when deleting images and snapshots with dependencies, etc. The
default value is null.

Co-Author-By: Sofia Enriquez <lsofia.enriquez@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Id8e581893ee4b373b268acc7c59b670985cedc2f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-plugin-ceph refs/changes/24/782624/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if is_ceph_enabled_for_service cinder; then # enables new features like Clone v2 API, which allows # for proper handling of the deletion of snapshots # with child clone images if vercmp "$ceph_version" ">=" "13.0"; then sudo ceph -c ${CEPH_CONF_FILE} \ osd set-require-min-compat-client mimic fi fi

subject: Always build universal wheels
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-10-04 02:08:53.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-pacemaker/commit/6b0ee249f8f612d1553add5b69d87f67bfa6f589', 'message': 'build universal wheels

By default setuptools produces a version-specific wheel file so
installation under other versions of Python require extra work at
install time. This change turns on "universal" wheel support, so that

commit_message:
Always build universal wheels

All of our projects are pure python, so we can build
universal wheels by default.

Change-Id: I5e27f05dd49eb761682cdb9174dbc6f9f476ff20

commit_message:
Update volume schema for microversion

Adding to the schema for volume show and creation:
- volume_type_id microverion 3.64
- encryption_key_id microverion 3.64
- cluster_name microverion 3.61
- volume_type_id microverion 3.63

Update volume backup schema
- encryption_key_id microverion 3.64

Create files per micro version under api_schema
Copy and update micro version between files,
Update volumes_client with schema_versions_info
Update backups_client with schema_versions_info

Change-Id: Ic96c8f94945caf0e202ce7f9f069247ec0f10a11

commit_message:
Keystone identity mapping to support project definition as a JSON

As discussed in the Keystone meeting [1], I am proposing this spec, so we can
review and discuss the implementation proposed in [2].

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/keystone/2020/keystone.2020-08-25-16.59.log.txt
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/742235

Implements: blueprint federated-identity-mapping-support-project-json-definition
RFE: https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/1888412
Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/keystone-specs/+/748042/

Change-Id: Ie9f2c3c56daabd925eabab6f935feb71f5011d60
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/48/748748/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================================= Keystone identity mapping to support project definition as a JSON ================================================================= This spec adds support for project definition as a JSON in Keystone identity federation attribute mapping schema This spec depends on https://review.opendev.org/#/c/748042/, which is the proposal that enhances the identity mapping schema management. Therefore, we first need to get that reviewed and merged. Problem Description =================== Currently, the project assignment via the federated identity mapping is rather static. This happens because of the find/replace mechanism that we have in place there. Therefore, if the IdP provider generates an attribute that contains a JSON with project definitions, we are not able to handle it in Keystone. Proposed Change =============== This PR introduces a new property in the federated identity mapping schema called `projects_json`. In the schema, this property will accept a JSON string, that defines all of the projects and their specific roles that the user must receive when login-in to the OpenStack platform. Moreover, when using this extension, roles (assigned to projects) are added and removed on the fly. The extension is quite straight forward. We created a new ``schema_version`` (1.2). This new version enables the handling of `project_json` in the attribute mapping. Furthermore, we added code to handle the addition of extra roles for projects and removal of roles that are present in OpenStack, but are not in the IdP data. This is a mechanism to make the state of the OpenStack federated user consistent with the Identity provider user attributes. Attribute mapping schema ------------------------ Adding the `project_json` attribute: .. code-block:: python IDP_ATTRIBUTE_MAPPING_SCHEMA_1_2 = copy.deepcopy( IDP_ATTRIBUTE_MAPPING_SCHEMA_1_1) IDP_ATTRIBUTE_MAPPING_SCHEMA_1_2['properties']['rules']['items']['properties'][ 'local']['items']['properties']['projects_json'] = {"type": "string"} By adding ``projects_json`` as a ``string``, we enable operators to use attributes in the IdP, that are a Json Strings which define the projects where the users must be placed in. Moreover, This JSON is then validated against the project definition. The new option will be handled in version ``1.2`` of the attribute mapping schema. Database table changes ---------------------- None API impacts ----------- None Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignees: - Rafael <rafael@apache.org> Other contributors: Work Items ---------- 1) Implement proposed changes in Keystone [1]_ - Create a new mapping schema - Create new processors for the proposed changes - Implement validations and unit tests - Update documentation Dependencies ============ None References ========== .. [1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/742235

commit_message:
Federation: add support for projects_json assertion

Currently Keystone mapping doesn't allow to assign dynamically roles on
a list of projects, like he does for assigning a list of groups. It
prevent to dynamically create all the necessary object to give access
 to Openstack to a user.

This patch add the ability to receive a projects_json from a claim of
your IdP, honoring the project list schema, to dynamically create and
assign role on a list of projects in Keystone.

Change-Id: I934df15aa1cbb6ceddd8d24b2fa803b6a6efb31e

added_lines: def test_mapping_projects_json(self): mapping = mapping_fixtures.MAPPING_PROJECTS_JSON assertion = mapping_fixtures.EMPLOYEE_JSON_ASSERTION rp = mapping_utils.RuleProcessor(FAKE_MAPPING_ID, mapping['rules']) values = rp.process(assertion) self.assertValidMappedUserObject(values) expected_user = mapping_fixtures.EMPLOYEE_JSON_ASSERTION['UserName'] self.assertEqual(expected_user, values['user']['name']) expected_projects = [ { "name": "Production", "roles": [{"name": "observer"}] }, { "name": "Staging", "roles": [{"name": "member"}] }, { "name": "Common", "domain": "Default", "roles": [{"name": "member"}] } ] self.assertEqual(expected_projects, values['projects'])

commit_message:
Add  another scenario testcase  test_minimum_basic

Current test used as a basic check for multiple services

- Changed the nova reboot to HARD in order to refresh connection for
  attahced devices
- Created a volume snapshot and delete it before reboot instance
- Write data to the attached volume and read post instance reboot.

Related-Bug: #1860913

Change-Id: I4151715954b3a12e6c790836d4b7bd50c0407720

commit_message:
Designate: clean up bind and worker rndc configuration

This patch simplifies the bind config ansible calls and moves the worker
related rndc configuration to the worker service where it was previously
hidden within the designate central service.

Change-Id: I7c1321216f8256b3d819ee437d0798eb7f592158

subject: Compute grafana_vip using net_vip_map instead of hiera
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-06-20 12:29:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ansible/commit/150f0a4faf96a09fff2445b2d4f0efd90be8f357', 'message': 'Compute VIPs using net_vip_map instead of hiera

This change provides two improvements:

1. VIPs are computed using the existing net_vip_map instead of running
   hiera commands;

2. the monitoring_stack_vip (on the storage network) is provided for
   both prometheus and alertmanager: these two services are not exposed
   but we need the ceph_mgr being aware about the vip.

Change-Id: Ibad723edaa2de9ffad896d8f85ca9b5c09aa0678

commit_message:
Compute grafana_vip using net_vip_map instead of hiera

This change fixes the way the grafana vip is computed: now it
uses the existing net_vip_map instead of running hiera commands
on the undercloud.

Change-Id: Ibad723edaa2de9ffad896d8f85ca9b5c09aa0678

commit_message:
Change minversion of tox to 3.18.0

The patch bumps min version of tox to 3.18.0 in order to
replace whitelist_externals with allowlist_externals option:
https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/blob/master/docs/changelog.rst#v3180-2020-07-23

Signed-off-by: Takashi Natsume <takanattie@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I35c8c1591c8da83eb2c681ef176eb3e3f3c2798f

subject: Avoid including bad service names in perf.json
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-06-23 16:27:18.000000000', 'files': ['tools/get-stats.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/fe7cfa6b8c7573d643d66d3684de03e4183651bb', 'message': 'Avoid including bad service names in perf.json

Some of the API services are not properly mounted under /$service/
in the apache proxy. This patch tries to avoid recording data
for "services" like "v2.0" (in the case of neutron) by only adding
names if they're all letters. A single warning is emitted for any
services excluded by this check.

For the moment this will mean we don't collect data for those services,
but when their devstack API config is fixed, they'll start to show
up.

Change-Id: I41cc300e89a4f97a008a8ba97c91f0980f9b9c3f
'}]
commit_message:
Avoid including bad service names in perf.json

Some of the API services are not properly mounted under /$service/
in the apache proxy. This patch tries to avoid recording data
for "services" like "v2.0" (in the case of neutron) by only adding
names if they're all letters. A single warning is emitted for any
services excluded by this check.

For the moment this will mean we don't collect data for those services,
but when their devstack API config is fixed, they'll start to show
up.

Change-Id: I41cc300e89a4f97a008a8ba97c91f0980f9b9c3f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/78/847378/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ignored_services = set() if not service.isalpha(): ignored_services.add(service) continue if ignored_services: LOG.warning('Ignored services: %s' % ','.join( sorted(ignored_services)))

commit_message:
Fullstack tests of packet rate limit for ovs qos driver

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-neutronclient/+/818717

Partially-Implements: bp/packet-rate-limit
Related-Bug: #1938966
Related-Bug: #1912460
Change-Id: If2d8f4e89987dcb55fcbef126a02bff4433c6aa8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/18/819418/13 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron.plugins.ml2.drivers.openvswitch.agent.common \ import constants as agent_constsPACKET_RATE_LIMIT = 10000 PACKET_RATE_BURST = 1000 class _TestPacketRateLimitQoS(BaseQoSRuleTestCase): number_of_hosts = 1 def _wait_for_packet_rate_limit_rule_applied(self, vm, direction): l2_extensions.wait_until_pkt_meter_rule_applied_ovs( vm.bridge, vm.port.name, vm.neutron_port['id'], direction, vm.mac_address) def _wait_for_packet_rate_limit_rule_removed(self, vm, direction): l2_extensions.wait_until_pkt_meter_rule_applied_ovs( vm.bridge, vm.port.name, vm.neutron_port['id'], direction) def _add_packet_rate_limit_rule(self, limit, burst, direction, qos_policy): qos_policy_id = qos_policy['id'] rule = self.safe_client.create_packet_rate_limit_rule( self.tenant_id, qos_policy_id, limit, burst, direction) rule['type'] = qos_consts.RULE_TYPE_PACKET_RATE_LIMIT rule['qos_policy_id'] = qos_policy_id qos_policy['rules'].append(rule) def _create_vm_with_limit_rules(self): # Create port with qos policy attached, with different direction vm, qos_policy = self._prepare_vm_with_qos_policy( [functools.partial( self._add_packet_rate_limit_rule, PACKET_RATE_LIMIT, PACKET_RATE_BURST, self.direction), functools.partial( self._add_packet_rate_limit_rule, PACKET_RATE_LIMIT, PACKET_RATE_BURST, self.reverse_direction)]) self._wait_for_packet_rate_limit_rule_applied( vm, self.direction) self._wait_for_packet_rate_limit_rule_applied( vm, self.reverse_direction) return vm, qos_policy def test_packet_rate_limit_qos_policy_rule_lifecycle(self): new_limit = PACKET_RATE_LIMIT + 100 # Create port with qos policy attached vm, qos_policy = self._prepare_vm_with_qos_policy( [functools.partial( self._add_packet_rate_limit_rule, PACKET_RATE_LIMIT, PACKET_RATE_BURST, self.direction)]) vm.bridge.use_at_least_protocol(agent_consts.OPENFLOW13) if not vm.bridge.list_meter_features(): self.skip("Test ovs bridge %s does not support meter.", vm.bridge.br_name) pkt_rule = qos_policy['rules'][0] self._wait_for_packet_rate_limit_rule_applied( vm, self.direction) qos_policy_id = qos_policy['id'] self.client.delete_packet_rate_limit_rule(pkt_rule['id'], qos_policy_id) self._wait_for_packet_rate_limit_rule_removed(vm, self.direction) new_rule = self.safe_client.create_packet_rate_limit_rule( self.tenant_id, qos_policy_id, new_limit, direction=self.direction) self._wait_for_packet_rate_limit_rule_applied( vm, self.direction) # Update qos policy rule id self.client.update_packet_rate_limit_rule( new_rule['id'], qos_policy_id, body={'packet_rate_limit_rule': { 'max_kpps': PACKET_RATE_LIMIT, 'max_burst_kpps': PACKET_RATE_BURST}}) self._wait_for_packet_rate_limit_rule_applied( vm, self.direction) # Remove qos policy from port self.client.update_port( vm.neutron_port['id'], body={'port': {'qos_policy_id': None}}) self._wait_for_packet_rate_limit_rule_removed(vm, self.direction) class TestPacketRateLimitQoSOvs(_TestPacketRateLimitQoS, base.BaseFullStackTestCase): l2_agent_type = constants.AGENT_TYPE_OVS scenarios = [ ('ingress', {'direction': constants.INGRESS_DIRECTION}), ('egress', {'direction': constants.EGRESS_DIRECTION}) ]

commit_message:
Correct hostname for OVN agent

Currently Devstack uses short hostname for configuration of OVN.
This leads to inability to start instances (failing port binding)
on hosts with full hostnames (including dots). Open vSwitch expects
hostname in external_ids that corresponds to one returned by
``hostname`` command.

Closes-Bug: #1943631
Change-Id: I15b71a49c482be0c8f15ad834e29ea1b33307c86

commit_message:
[OpenStackAnsible] Release OpenStack Ansible Yoga RC1 and cut branch

This release patch is to ensure, that trailing typed projects have been
branched for Yoga. The deadline for these deliverables is June 23rd.

Please +1 if the team is ready for us to proceed with this or update/-1
if something should be changed.

Change-Id: I2cce89594c1b465666776a21fdc784053e279785

commit_message:
Update CI to use unversioned jobs template

As part of the migration of this project to the independent release
model, we failed to notice that the job template was still tied to a
specific release. We've now introduced a new unversioned job template,
'openstack-python3-jobs' [1], which was can and should use. Do this.

Note that this is effectively a revert of change
Ic93f1c77230d859713ea9bc86065880efa91de7c which attempted to resolve the
same problem in a different way.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-zuul-jobs/+/833286/

Change-Id: Ibf1238bc7c09b4ae9824be81a06f22decfb40873
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-zuul-jobs/+/833286/
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Move Victoria for Tripleo Repos to End Of Life

As proposed at [1] and [2] this moves stable/victoria
branch for all tripleo related repos to end of life.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2022-June/028829.html
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2022-June/029169.html
Change-Id: Idecf1e2ca8a03c075c189054f4a9b73edce151b1

commit_message:
Update python testing as per zed cycle testing runtime

In Zed cycle, we have dropped the python 3.6/3.7[1] testing
and its support. Removing the py36 centos8 job as well as
updating the python classifier also to reflect the same.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/zed.html

Change-Id: Ice183a1f7e19e238241cba4eb5710f47be586b5f

commit_message:
setup.cfg: Replace dashes with underscores

Setuptools v54.1.0 introduces a warning that the use of dash-separated
options in 'setup.cfg' will not be supported in a future version [1].
Get ahead of the issue by replacing the dashes with underscores. Without
this, we see 'UserWarning' messages like the following on new enough
versions of setuptools:

  UserWarning: Usage of dash-separated 'description-file' will not be
  supported in future versions. Please use the underscore name
  'description_file' instead

[1] https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/commit/a2e9ae4cb

Change-Id: I56777ed65d2b8d7183c4c6430889f695f0a9ef61
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-resource-classes refs/changes/61/788861/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update Python testing as oer zed cycle testing runtime

We have dropped support for Python 3.6 and 3.7 [1] in the Zed cycle.
Remove official support for these versions and clean up the Zuul job
definitions to use the unversioned 'openstack-python3-jobs' project
template instead of listing a duplicate set of tested runtimes.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/zed.html

Change-Id: I3d30b1eefecb961bf1eca112a097bc85c73ef1a2
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Override Ceph --container-namespace for periodic jobs

If the standalone job is periodic, use 'openstack overcloud
ceph deploy --container-namespace' to pull the container
directly from quay.rdoproject.org.

Standalone scenarios usually consume containers from a
content-provider but periodic jobs pull them directly
from quay.rdoproject.org. The periodic jobs then push
them to the undercloud as a container registry. Non-
periodic jobs do not push to the undercloud registry.

When I982dedb53582fbd76391165c3ca72954c129b84a merged,
periodic standalone jobs broke because the undercloud
container registry was not configured when 'openstack
overcloud ceph deploy' was run. Because the container
prepare file has a push_destination, deployed ceph
assumes the containers were prepared in advance so it
swaps out the container namespace as indicated by
push_destination directive. Though this still happens
we override it again with --container-namespace.

Change-Id: I1abfbbd23ca93c01393d05057806ba9cc846fbed
Closes-bug: #1978998

commit_message:
Add a release note for 834162

I forgot to write a release note when pushing change 834162 [1].
It may be an important change for operators so it's good to have a
release note about that.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/834162

Related-Bug: #1952907
Change-Id: Ie707f461af11357d6eaa004bc98c7eb09a62202f

added_lines: # Begin cinder service classes class BaseCinderService(BaseService): def __init__(self, manager, **kwargs): super(BaseCinderService, self).__init__(kwargs) self.backups_client = manager.backups_client_latest self.groups_client = manager.groups_client_latest self.group_snapshots_client = manager.group_snapshots_client_latest self.group_types_client = manager.group_types_client_latest self.snapshots_client = manager.snapshots_client_latest self.volumes_client = manager.volumes_client_latest self.quotas_client = manager.volume_quotas_client_latest def _init_data(self, service_name): if not self.data.has_key(service_name): self.data[service_name] = {} class BackupsService(BaseCinderService): def list(self): backups = self.backups_client.list_backups(self.project_id)['backups'] LOG.debug("List count, %s Backups in %s project" % (len(backups), self.project_id)) return backups def delete(self): backups = self.list() client = self.backups_client for backup in backups: try: client.delete_backup(project_id=self.project_id, backup_id=backup['id']) except Exception: LOG.exception("Delete Backup exception.") def dry_run(self): self._init_data('backups') backups = self.list() self.data['backups'][self.project_id] = {} for b in backups: self.data['backups'][self.project_id][b['id']] = b['name'] class GroupsService(BaseCinderService): def list(self): groups = self.groups_client.list_groups(self.project_id)['groups'] LOG.debug("List count, %s Groups in %s project" % (len(groups), self.project_id)) return groups def delete(self): groups = self.list() client = self.groups_client for group in groups: try: client.delete_group(project_id=self.project_id, group_id=group['id']) except Exception: LOG.exception("Delete Groups exception.") def dry_run(self): self._init_data('groups') groups = self.list() self.data['groups'][self.project_id] = {} for g in groups: self.data['groups'][self.project_id][g['id']] = g['name'] class GroupSnapshotsService(BaseCinderService): def list(self): client = self.group_snapshots_client snaps = client.list_groups(self.project_id)['group_snapshots'] LOG.debug("List count, %s Group Snapshots in %s project" % (len(snaps), self.project_id)) return snaps def delete(self): snaps = self.list() client = self.group_snapshots_client for snap in snaps: try: client.delete_group_snapshot( project_id=self.project_id, group_snapshot_id=snap['id']) except Exception: LOG.exception("Delete Group Snapshot exception.") def dry_run(self): self._init_data('group_snapshots') snaps = self.list() self.data['group_snapshots'][self.project_id] = {} for s in snaps: self.data['group_snapshots'][self.project_id][s['id']] = s['name'] class GroupTypesService(BaseCinderService): def list(self): client = self.group_types_client types = client.list_groups(self.project_id)['group_types'] LOG.debug("List count, %s Group Types in %s project" % (len(types), self.project_id)) return types def delete(self): types = self.list() client = self.group_types_client for type in types: try: specs = client.list_group_type_specs( project_id=self.project_id, group_type_id=type['id']) for spec_key in specs['group_specs'].keys(): client.delete_group_type_specs_item( project_id=self.project_id, group_type_id=type['id'], spec_id=spec_key) client.delete_group_type(project_id=self.project_id, group_type_id=type['id']) except Exception: LOG.exception("Delete Group Type exception.") def dry_run(self): self._init_data('group_types') types = self.list() self.data['group_types'][self.project_id] = {} for t in types: self.data['group_types'][self.project_id][t['id']] = t['name'] class SnapshotService(BaseCinderService): def list(self): snaps = self.snapshots_client.list_snapshots()['snapshots'] if not self.is_save_state: # recreate list removing saved snapshots snaps = [snap for snap in snaps if snap['id'] not in self.saved_state_json['snapshots'].keys()] LOG.debug("List count, %s Snapshots", len(snaps)) return snaps def delete(self): snaps = self.list() client = self.snapshots_client for snap in snaps: try: client.delete_snapshot(snap['id']) except Exception: LOG.exception("Delete Snapshot exception.") def dry_run(self): snaps = self.list() self.data['snapshots'] = snaps def save_state(self): snaps = self.list() self.data['snapshots'] = {} for snap in snaps: self.data['snapshots'][snap['id']] = snap['name'] class VolumeService(BaseCinderService): def list(self): vols = self.volumes_client.list_volumes()['volumes'] if not self.is_save_state: # recreate list removing saved volumes vols = [vol for vol in vols if vol['id'] not in self.saved_state_json['volumes'].keys()] LOG.debug("List count, %s Volumes", len(vols)) return vols def delete(self): vols = self.list() client = self.volumes_client for v in vols: try: client.delete_volume(v['id']) except Exception: LOG.exception("Delete Volume exception.") def dry_run(self): vols = self.list() self.data['volumes'] = vols def save_state(self): vols = self.list() self.data['volumes'] = {} for vol in vols: self.data['volumes'][vol['id']] = vol['name'] class VolumeQuotaService(BaseCinderService): def delete(self): client = self.quotas_client try: client.delete_quota_set(self.project_id) except Exception: LOG.exception("Delete Volume Quotas exception.") def dry_run(self): self._init_data('volume_quotas') quotas = self.client.show_quota_set( self.project_id, params={'usage': True})['quota_set'] self.data['volume_quotas'][self.project_id] = quotas project_services.append(BackupsService) project_services.append(GroupSnapshotsService) project_services.append(GroupsService) project_services.append(GroupTypesService)

commit_message:
Add step of wait for server termination

After last step of deleting server, it doesn't wait for the server to be
deleted, then it tries to delele floating ip immediately in the cleanup, which
will cause failure. Seems nova now fails to handle the scenario of deleting
both server and floating ip at the same time. So add a step of wait for server
termination to avoid failure in the following step of deleting floating ip.

Change-Id: I5e2d08863974301c008c5f3a54b78a2389b0a1e3
Closes-Bug: #1586931

commit_message:
account-generator forbid negative concurrency, add unit tests

Test coverage of tempest account-generator for config and account file

Adding test cases of tempest account-generator on basis of config
and account parameters used in command.

tempest account generator was accepting zero or negative
value for concurrency parameter and resulting in blank
accounts.yaml file which is wrong behavior.

Partially-Implements: blueprint tempest-cli-unit-test-coverage

Change-Id: If6968c9908bc5ae764f6943dfc6194d5b28b7b34
Closes-Bug: #1811349

added_lines: if opts.concurrency <= 0: raise ValueError("Concurrency value should be positive integer")

commit_message:
Support multiple backends in keystone v3 admin test

The tests for list users and groups in the Keystone v3 admin tests
fail when Keystone is configured to use domain-specific
identity drivers. When "domain_specific_drivers_enabled" is set true.
The list_groups,list_groups,list_users_with_name operations in tempest
will get the groups,users scoped the domain owned the current user,
so we can't get other domain's groups,users. This patch fix this bug.

Co-Authored-By: ZhangHongtao<zhanghongtao0826@126.com>
Change-Id: I2abada9bab705a0f2bfb0b6e210dd5d3ca3c70e8
Closes-Bug: 1614758

added_lines: import testtools from tempest import configCONF = config.CONF if CONF.identity_feature_enabled.multiple_backends: params['domain_id'] = self.domain['id'] @testtools.skipIf(CONF.identity_feature_enabled.multiple_backends, 'Multiple domain backends')

subject: Support setting Nova API microversion for openstack-exporter

the maximum version still providing this data.

commit_message:
Support setting Nova API microversion for openstack-exporter

Starting from v1.5.0 of the exporter, OS_COMPUTE_API_VERSION can be set
to configure the Nova API version to be used [1]. Microversion 2.1 can
be used to keep metrics unmodified from the previous exporter version
deployed by Kolla (v1.3.0).

Support it with prometheus_openstack_exporter_compute_api_version,
defaulting to using the latest version.

[1] https://github.com/openstack-exporter/openstack-exporter/pull/201

Change-Id: I7605a3f9f74effb29ecec3b28e4709fd5f7f8cd4

commit_message:
Fix DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence for py36

This commit fixes warnings "DeprecationWarning: invalid escape
sequence" for Python3.6. The warnings occur from Python3.6 and it
doesn't occur in both Python2.7 and 3.5 in the gate. However, according
to the document[1], the warning will eventually become a SyntaxError
after several Python releases. This fixing should be better for the
changing.

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.6.html#deprecated-python-behavior

Change-Id: I21cd523c4f37447f7d1397b3a8830a6a58bc9a6d

commit_message:
cinder-backup/volume: Remove unused parameters

This cleans up unused parameters from cinder-backup/volume templates.

- DeployIdentifier is not used by *-pacemaker-puppet.yaml

- *LoggingSource is used only by *-container-puppet.yaml and is
  inherited using resource definition + get_attr. The parameter is
  not directly used by *-pacemaker-puppet.yaml.

- Enable(Etcd)InternalTLS is now used by the common template and is not
  used directly by the cinder-volume template.

- CephCongigPath is not directly used by the cinder-volume template. It
  is used by the common template.

Change-Id: I181c7357a0cfdb90ddd103b276d02a182df40b1d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/70/845870/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Deprecates tripleo-ansible-inventory and remove tripleo-validation scripts

tripleo-ansible-inventory is broken in Master/Wallaby and need to be revisit

* tripleo-ansible with the playbook cli-config-download.yaml offers a way to

with the current VF CLI.

tripleo-ansible-inventory is broken in Master/Wallaby and need to be revisit

commit_message:
Deprecates tripleo-ansible-inventory and remove tripleo-validation scripts

tripleo-ansible-inventory is broken in Master/Wallaby and need to be revisit
to what tripleo is actually deploying:
* tripleo-deploy directory contains a valid inventory
* tripleo-ansible with the playbook cli-config-download.yaml offers a way to
  regenerate a fresh inventory.

This review also removed the scripts/tripleo-validation.py which is not longer functional
with the current VF CLI.

Change-Id: Ie02259336c763cfa980b59ad64f9e478d05690fb
Closes-Bug: #1936406
Resolves: rhbz#2008426
(cherry picked from commit 08e2e1a060332bb5dfba4e9b52d526d2272dd343)

commit_message:
Remove options for oslo.db thread pool support

Thread pool support in oslo.db was already deprecated[1], and it is not
actually used by Glance.

[1] 74c6bf266e0b86ceb4726cad9268f134d423bae8

Change-Id: I79e934f34f33953c821b6529a34e44dcf2a9688c

commit_message:
Do not try to get new job results when none available

When the new Zuul tenant is deployed, it can be a situation that
none job has been done, so the logscraper cat get an infinity loop.

Change-Id: Id0125f52d4cf2190bfa2aea7deec75fd6b9ab06a

added_lines: parser.add_argument("--config", help="Logscraper config file")def get_config_args(config_path): config_file = load_config(config_path) if config_file and 'logscraper' in config_file: return config_file['logscraper'] def parse_args(app_args, config_args): delattr(app_args, 'config') for k, v in config_args.items(): setattr(app_args, k, v) return app_args app_args = get_arguments() config_args = get_config_args(app_args.config) args = parse_args(app_args, config_args)

commit_message:
Do not end ceph_namespace with a slash

The parse_container_image_prepare utility function
incorrectly appends a slash to the ceph_namespace tag
it extracts from the container image prepare file. Use
not '/'.join but os.path.normpath of os.path.join.

Change-Id: I47e55b33ae70e1a6de141bf96c0080b730dc2966
Closes-Bug: #1979554

commit_message:
Return facts gathering to pre_tasks for masakari

We don't have pacemaker_corosync_ring_interface defined outside of
pacemaker_corosync_group and it won't be consistent across hosts.
As it might include mix of containers/bare metal hosts, so interface
name might be inconsistent.

So let's not bring too much complexity for default option and just
revert to old good working solution.

This partially reverts change Ie996262043edb8fb9c7221a5cd98e98a0111ac28
and I75bdab29353f33fa009bf9a7ff1f565f1660ed59

Closes-Bug: #1979145
Change-Id: I4099c66fd37813b6a4c6e5b8a312a12647969e71
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/80/846580/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

This made a lot of sense. This patch does the same thing for formpost. It adds a new `formpost` sub command to the swiftclient shell. And a generate formpost signature helper method to utils, so now we can: $ swift formpost "/v1/a/c" 5 1 500 "some_key" \ --redirect 'http://gohere.example' --algorithm sha256 /v1/a/c, 5, 1, 500, some_key Expires: 1647412026 Signature: sha256:287d48fb089e35a537807e3579cdfd099ef285894011680a48f41855b4860b25 Sample form: NOTE: the
tag's "action" attribute does not obtain the Swift cluster's hostname. You should manually add it before using the form.
Where the order of commands are: $ swift formpost --help Usage: swift formpost [--algorithm ] [--redirect ] Generate Form Signature positional arguments: path The prefix to use for form uploaded objects. For example: /v1/account/container/object_prefix_ would ensure all form uploads have that path prepended to the browser-given file name. max_file_size The maximum file size per file uploaded. max_file_count The maximum number of uploaded files allowed. seconds The number of seconds from now to allow the form post to begin. key The X-{Account|Container}-Meta-Temp-URL-Key for the account/container. optional arguments: --redirect The URL to redirect the browser to after the uploads have completed. --algorithm {sha256,sha512,sha1}, -a {sha256,sha512,sha1} Select the hash algorithm to use. The default algorithm/digest is sha512. The default algorithm/digest is sha256. Change-Id: Idd318c7bdddea60e8ede7e310b51a270e93f764f '}]
commit_message:
Add formpost subcommand to generate signature A couple of years ago[0] we moved the tempurl signature generation from a tool inside swift to a sub command in the client. This made a lot of sense. This patch does the same thing for formpost. It adds a new `formpost` sub command to the swiftclient shell. And a generate formpost signature helper method to utils, so now we can: $ swift formpost "/v1/a/c" 5 1 500 "some_key" \ --redirect 'http://gohere.example' --algorithm sha256 /v1/a/c, 5, 1, 500, some_key Expires: 1647412026 Signature: 287d48fb089e35a537807e3579cdfd099ef285894011680a48f41855b4860b25 Sample form: NOTE: the
tag's "action" attribute does not obtain the Swift cluster's hostname. You should manually add it before using the form.
Where the order of commands are: $ swift formpost --help Usage: swift formpost [--digest ] [--redirect ] Generate Form Signature positional arguments: path The prefix to use for form uploaded objects. For example: /v1/account/container/object_prefix_ would ensure all form uploads have that path prepended to the browser-given file name. max_file_size The maximum file size per file uploaded. max_file_count The maximum number of uploaded files allowed. seconds The number of seconds from now to allow the form post to begin. key The X-{Account|Container}-Meta-Temp-URL-Key for the account/container. optional arguments: --redirect The URL to redirect the browser to after the uploads have completed. --digest {sha256,sha512,sha1} Select the hash algorithm to use. The default algorithm/digest is sha256. Change-Id: Idd318c7bdddea60e8ede7e310b51a270e93f764f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-swiftclient refs/changes/54/833954/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch('swiftclient.shell.generate_formpost_sig', return_value=('some_sig', 0, 'form_data')) def test_temp_url(self, formpost): argv = ["", "formpost", "/v1/a/c", "5", "6", "300", "secret_key"] swiftclient.shell.main(argv) formpost.assert_called_with( u'/v1/a/c', u'5', u'6', u'300', u'secret_key', redirect=u'', algorithm=u'sha512') @mock.patch('swiftclient.shell.generate_formpost_sig', return_value=('some_sig', 0, 'form_data')) def test_temp_url_with_redirect(self, formpost): argv = ["", "formpost", "--redirect", "some_redirect", "/v1/a/c", "5", "6", "300", "secret_key"] swiftclient.shell.main(argv) formpost.assert_called_with( u'/v1/a/c', u'5', u'6', u'300', u'secret_key', redirect=u'some_redirect', algorithm=u'sha512') @mock.patch('swiftclient.shell.generate_formpost_sig', return_value=('some_sig', 0, 'form_data')) def test_temp_url_different_algorithm(self, formpost): argv = ["", "formpost", "--algorithm", "sha256", "/v1/a/c", "5", "6", "300", "secret_key"] swiftclient.shell.main(argv) formpost.assert_called_with( u'/v1/a/c', u'5', u'6', u'300', u'secret_key', redirect=u'', algorithm=u'sha256')

commit_message:
Bump oslo.* and pbr version to support >=py38

In zed cycle, OpenStack projects and oslo lib
has dropped the py3.6 and py3.7 support

- https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/zed.html

I also decrepated oslo-log < 5.0.0, so we should bump oslo.log>=5.0.0.

Because of oslo.log>=5.0.0 depends on oslo.i18n>=3.20.0 as below, so we
also need to upgrade oslo.i18n.

The conflict is caused by:
    The user requested oslo.utils>=3.33.0
    oslo-log 5.0.0 depends on oslo.utils>=3.36.0
    The user requested (constraint) oslo-utils==3.33.0

Change-Id: I9e52deda308339f7b0f1f8138dcf0345ccaa37cb

commit_message:
Add support for min_speed percentage of link speed

This can be useful for environments with mixed link speeds.

Example:

```
juju config magpie min_speed=80%
```

Further note on behaviour: if a percentage min_speed is set,
and the link is virtual or otherwise returns a negative speed,
magpie will fail the speed check.
(percentage of an undefined value is still undefined)

Closes-Bug: #1977784

Change-Id: I1fa5d38a4da26ca38e98350d1a1625184dff2363
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-magpie refs/changes/84/845084/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_status_for_speed_check(self): self.assertEqual( magpie_tools.status_for_speed_check('0', 123, 150), ', 123 mbit/s' ) self.assertEqual( magpie_tools.status_for_speed_check('0%', 123, 150), ', 123 mbit/s' ) self.assertEqual( magpie_tools.status_for_speed_check(':P', 123, 150), ", invalid min_speed: ':P'" ) self.assertEqual( magpie_tools.status_for_speed_check('1', 10, 400), ', speed ok: 10 mbit/s' ) self.assertEqual( magpie_tools.status_for_speed_check('12', 10, 400), ', speed failed: 10 < 12 mbit/s' ) self.assertEqual( magpie_tools.status_for_speed_check('50%', 100, 400), ', speed failed: 100 < 200 mbit/s' ) self.assertEqual( magpie_tools.status_for_speed_check('50%', 200, 400), ', speed ok: 200 mbit/s' ) self.assertEqual( magpie_tools.status_for_speed_check('50%', 300, 400), ', speed ok: 300 mbit/s' )

commit_message:
Fix backend options missing from glance-cache.conf

The glance-cache.conf file is used by the glance-cache-prefetcher
command. This command requires access to backend stores so that it can
pull image data, but currently backend parameters are not fully added
to glance-cache.conf thus the command can't obtain full access to
backends properly.

This change ensures all parameters related to backend are added to
the glance-cache.conf file in addition to the glance-api.conf file.

Change-Id: I30f895185f195bfa92aeee5e58c70421eff6901d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-glance refs/changes/83/846783/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # glance-cache.conf is not used by daemons, so we do not need to restart # glance services even after the file is updated. Anchor['glance::config::begin'] -> Glance_cache_config<||> -> Anchor['glance::config::end']

commit_message:
Add support for Zed

* sync charm-helpers to classic charms
* rebuild for reactive charms
* add new zed bundles
* add zed bundles to tests.yaml
* add zed tests to osci.yaml and .zuul.yaml

Change-Id: I507c376957c69c256405f202a5e8b444a6076b91

revisions:

The patch does similar to what

implements in puppet. However, the puppet changes are not

Change-Id: Ic0334aaad83bd94b604fbd84fcc21d3520e9d400

commit_message:
Add mac-size-table to all OVS bridges

The default mac table size may not be sufficient for the
provider bridges. If the mac table overflows, it has been
observed that ovs-vswitchd clocks 100% CPU. So this patch
configures the mac table size of the provider bridges.

The patch does similar to what
https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ovn/commit/88aa5c9184f8f448aed499413cda51188d66c7a6
implements in puppet. However, the puppet changes are not
persistent across reboots, therefore it's better to save it
in the OVS database.

Change-Id: Ic0334aaad83bd94b604fbd84fcc21d3520e9d400
Related-bug: #1779706
Signed-off-by: Jakub Libosvar <libosvar@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit d8c7e7ed83af103b3bb03a173d3dc1d3e2a58b9a)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-net-config refs/changes/80/844080/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: MAC_TABLE_SIZE = 50000 ovs_extra.append("set bridge %s other-config:mac-table-size=%d" % (base_opt.name, MAC_TABLE_SIZE))

subject: etcd: fix service config to work with latest versions
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-06-22 15:29:02.000000000', 'files': ['deployment/etcd/etcd-container-puppet.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/5e05f778b5f1ab6f33eb1f006cef9f3bbf26c937', 'message': "etcd: fix service config to work with latest versions

This patch fixes a problem with OpenStack tooz's etcd3gw
driver when it attempts to communicate with the etcd service.
The tooz driver uses etcd's grpc gateway functionality, but
starting with etcd v3.3 the grpc gateway is not enabled by
default (for wallaby, centos-8 includes etcd v3.2, but
centos-9 incudes v3.4).

Per [1], the fix involves adding a small config change to the
etcd config file.

[1] https://github.com/etcd-io/etcd/issues/12093#issuecomment-691575955

Normally this would be handled by puppet-etcd, but that puppet
module is *not* an opendev project, and is quite out of date.
It would take a lot of work to update puppet-etcd, with little
benefit beyond supporting [1].

The solution implemented here is to enhance the puppet_config
tasks to add the missing config after puppet-etcd finishes. The
long term solution is to replace puppet-etcd with a tripleo-ansible
role, but that's a larger effort.

This patch also removes the container_puppet_tasks that were
originally intended so tripleo could inject key/value pairs into
etcd. However, that functionality was never utilized, and is
currently broken due to it mounting etcd's database directory
in read-only mode. The container_puppet_tasks need to be removed
in order for the new puppet_config tasks to work correctly.

Resolves: rhbz#2097058
Change-Id: I3ed29a14298f4df94b8a5520615bfa85cd291346
(cherry picked from commit 796f6a5dca0490ece697565722652b4e5c2b4764)
"}]
commit_message:
etcd: fix service config to work with latest versions

This patch fixes a problem with OpenStack tooz's etcd3gw
driver when it attempts to communicate with the etcd service.
The tooz driver uses etcd's grpc gateway functionality, but
starting with etcd v3.3 the grpc gateway is not enabled by
default (for wallaby, centos-8 includes etcd v3.2, but
centos-9 incudes v3.4).

Per [1], the fix involves adding a small config change to the
etcd config file.

[1] https://github.com/etcd-io/etcd/issues/12093#issuecomment-691575955

Normally this would be handled by puppet-etcd, but that puppet
module is *not* an opendev project, and is quite out of date.
It would take a lot of work to update puppet-etcd, with little
benefit beyond supporting [1].

The solution implemented here is to enhance the puppet_config
tasks to add the missing config after puppet-etcd finishes. The
long term solution is to replace puppet-etcd with a tripleo-ansible
role, but that's a larger effort.

This patch also removes the container_puppet_tasks that were
originally intended so tripleo could inject key/value pairs into
etcd. However, that functionality was never utilized, and is
currently broken due to it mounting etcd's database directory
in read-only mode. The container_puppet_tasks need to be removed
in order for the new puppet_config tasks to work correctly.

Resolves: rhbz#2097058
Change-Id: I3ed29a14298f4df94b8a5520615bfa85cd291346
(cherry picked from commit 796f6a5dca0490ece697565722652b4e5c2b4764)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/84/847184/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - "file_line { 'etcd enable-grpc-gateway':" - " path => '/etc/etcd/etcd.yml'," - " line => 'enable-grpc-gateway: true'," - "}" puppet_tags: etcd_config
deleted_lines: container_puppet_tasks: # Etcd keys initialization occurs only on single node step_2: config_volume: 'etcd_init_tasks' puppet_tags: 'etcd_key' step_config: | include tripleo::profile::base::etcd config_image: *etcd_config_image # TODO(mwhahaha): need to check if this works correctly or we need to switch to a bootstrap execution volumes: - /var/lib/config-data/puppet-generated/etcd/etc/etcd/:/etc/etcd:ro - /var/lib/etcd:/var/lib/etcd:ro

commit_message:
metalsmith_instances module, unprovision by hostname

The node lookup for unprovision first attempts the allocation name
(hostname)[1] but the metalsmith_instances unprovision passes the node
name.

This means in cases where the node naming scheme and the allocation
naming scheme are the same, the wrong node may be unprovisioned.

This change switches to passing the hostname for unprovision, only
passing the node name if the hostname is missing from the instances
entry.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/metalsmith/src/branch/master/metalsmith/_provisioner.py#L653

Change-Id: Ie6b989f8d67c03606be37310777175cfb8d9303e
Resolves: rhbz#2092444

commit_message:
metalsmith_instances module, pass hostname in reserve

The allocation name/hostname is set during the provision step, but it
is also possible to set it during the reserve step, which is done in
this change.

Setting the name during reservation is more correct, and triggers some
extra sanity checks during provision. But it also enables this change[1]
which attempts to reserve the node with the same name as the
allocation.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ironic/+/845856

Change-Id: I0da4644a955b8e9fbf509c074b939b97c64739cb

commit_message:
metalsmith list handle missing port

Currently if a port is missing, running metalsmith list will fail with
an error. This change handles missing ports by not showing any IP
address for that VIF, and logging a warning.

Change-Id: I94924ebc81b46a2aa4c3b6f82bd46480f37b3150
Resolves: rhbz#2092444

commit_message:
Restore missing SAN IP in etcd cert

This patch fixes a regression in the etcd cert that is used with
tls-everywhere. The etcd service makes cluster connections using
its IP address, so with tls-e the etcd cert needs to include its
address as a SAN IP. The SAN IP was inadvertently dropped when
cert generation was moved from puppet to an ansible role.

Resolves: rhbz#2096230
Change-Id: I28e268c58bf63aaa81a67f48ca492fe97d9a07e9
(cherry picked from commit 9ed1c7b9209609dbdd6b59cf5cd94cfb3a290d1c)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/83/847183/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # etcd3 expects to use IP addresses, so add a SAN IP to its cert ip: str_replace: template: "{{NETWORK_ip}}" params: NETWORK: {get_param: [ServiceNetMap, EtcdNetwork]}

commit_message:
Add element reset-bls-entries

This is an element which will run a script on first boot to rename
`/boot/loader/entries` filenames to match the new value of
`/etc/machine-id`. This is required for `grub2-mkconfig` calls to
incorporate existing values in the boot loader entry files.

It only runs when first-boot criteria is met, such as when
`uninitialized` is written to `/etc/machine-id`

rhbz#2073855

Change-Id: I354aeabed6d2993ae600b86381a7b625ca7f89dc
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/diskimage-builder/+/837251
(cherry picked from commit 7fd9cbef64548e2f982d69f3a9ab277da63cb4f9)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/86/840386/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/usr/bin/bash set -eux pushd /boot/loader/entries machine_id=$(</etc/machine-id) for entry in *.conf; do new_entry=$(echo $entry | sed "s/^[a-f0-9]*/$machine_id/") if [[ $entry != $new_entry ]]; then echo "renaming $entry to $new_entry for new machine-id" mv $entry $new_entry fi done popd

commit_message:
Support to configure cinder backend_defaults

This patch does the inclusion of puppet-cinder Class
cinder::backend::defaults, that provides a way to configure
parameters for all cinder backends by default in
[backend_defaults] section of cinder configuration file.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/puppet-cinder/+/845652
Change-Id: Iadadfe253fb361af69b35c57e14c1f3ff4c036ea

commit_message:
Fix duplicate resources

This change fixes the duplicate resources between glance::api and
glance::backend::file, which were caused by the new parameters added
to the glance::backend::multistore::file defined type in [1].

[1] aaa352a3af310b184a3959da408ab5e9e7230eb2

Closes-Bug #1979232
Change-Id: Ib2f89a46d483f70c91e5fc444a84e968b79dae8e
(cherry picked from commit 0495848983374b52ac2fa394e0ceb416cf2fac36)

commit_message:
Add a link to the Large Scale SIG docs

The Large Scale SIG has started to publish their documentation at [0],
migrating content from the Wiki[1]. Add a link to the main landing page
and also add the repo to the _IGNORED_REPOS list in www-generator.py,
since it doesn't use the /latest/ patch as it is branchless and not
release-specific.

[0] https://docs.openstack.org/large-scale/index.html
[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Large_Scale_SIG

Change-Id: Ie7f297615d746f36f24e63ee3f25b4938e6f45e3

commit_message:
Update documentation about installation methods

config_template historically was published on PyPi during times before
collections were a thing. This was one of the installations methods
that is not relevant or preffered since collections are here.

That patch aims to update documentation about ways of plugin
installation as well as adding deprecation notice of PyPi.

In the futher releases we will drop publishing on PyPi.

Change-Id: Ie1cd7b305b4d82fd0fbf4568ef20ff3d0236c049

commit_message:
Set owner/permissions on ~/.tripleo for tripleo deploy

tripleo deploy is often executed as root. The generated history file
directory at ~/.tripleo needs to have the owner and permissions reset to
the deployment user.

Change-Id: I1d75cbd5d435ed2ab1bb6c6e5d4e7e6a434661de
Signed-off-by: James Slagle <jslagle@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Ie5a9d4821e104ed31dcddd540ac9467bfdba2125

commit_message:
Charmhub migration for stable/train (bionic-only)

This is the main patch for the migration of the stable/21.10
charm to charmhub for the stable/train branch (train track on
charmhub).  This patch initially supports bionic from queens
to train, and does not support ussuri.  It supports upgrades
from bionic-queens to bionic-train (with each intermediate
step needed).  Crucially it does NOT set a default
openstack-origin, which means installing train/stable
without specifying the openstack-origin will result in a
bionic-queens installation.  This is intentional as the branch
covers queens to train.

Change-Id: Ie5a9d4821e104ed31dcddd540ac9467bfdba2125
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-keystone-ldap refs/changes/10/847210/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: allowlist_externals = charmcraft bash tox rename.shdeps = -r{toxinidir}/build-requirements.txt commands = charmcraft clean charmcraft -v build {toxinidir}/rename.sh [testenv:build-reactive] basepython = python3[testenv:func-target] # Hack to get functional tests working in the charmcraft # world. We should fix this. basepython = python3 passenv = HOME TERM CS_* OS_* TEST_* deps = -r{toxinidir}/src/test-requirements.txt changedir = {toxinidir}/src commands = bash -c "if [ ! -f ../*.charm ]; then echo 'Charm does not exist. Run tox -e build'; exit 1; fi" tox --version tox -e func-target {posargs}

commit_message:
Updates to enable jammy and finalise charmcraft builds

- Add 22.04 to charmcraft.yaml
- Update metadata to include jammy
- Remove impish from metadata
- Update osci.yaml to include py3.10 default job
- Modify tox.ini to remove py35,py36,py37 tox target and add py310
  target.
- Pin tempest for python<3.8

Change-Id: Ia9a713625aa933fe99722df36f42a800af19c790
(cherry picked from commit 7195f3cda2690f5981fcc27237f2e937cc68c201)

This reverts commit f6c60d1d9c79a8048df7cc63fddb2b081eac430f.

The original patch referred as duplicated code the part where the

commit_message:
Revert "Cleanup code duplication in cinder.cmd.backup module"

This reverts commit f6c60d1d9c79a8048df7cc63fddb2b081eac430f.

The original patch referred as duplicated code the part where the
service uses a single process when there is no additional processes
requested (backup_workers == 1), which is the default.

That code made the cinder-backup service always run as a child process
even when there was only going to be 1 process.

This adds 30MB of extra RAM consumption by the service, which amounts to
a 30% unnecessary memory increase when not doing operations after
applying changes from Ic9030d01468b3189350f83b04a8d1d346c489d3c.

Change-Id: I43a20c8687f12bc52b014611cc6977c4c3ca212c

commit_message:
Charmhub migration for stable/train (bionic-only)

This is the main patch for the migration of the stable/21.10
charm to charmhub for the stable/train branch (train track on
charmhub).  This patch initially supports bionic from queens
to train, and does not support ussuri.  It supports upgrades
from bionic-queens to bionic-train (with each intermediate
step needed).  Crucially it does NOT set a default
openstack-origin, which means installing train/stable
without specifying the openstack-origin will result in a
bionic-queens installation.  This is intentional as the branch
covers queens to train.

Change-Id: Id3eef25a5d8287969da370e6d8d6693583d3c45d

We should fix this. basepython = python3 passenv = HOME TERM CS_* OS_* TEST_* deps = -r{toxinidir}/src/test-requirements.txt changedir = {toxinidir}/src commands = bash -c "if [ ! -f ../*.charm ]; then echo 'Charm does not exist. Run tox -e build'; exit 1; fi" tox --version tox -e func-target {posargs}

commit_message:
Migrate charm charmhub for stable/victoria

- start from stable/victoria branch
- Do charmcraft, osci, zuul changes
- Modify libs to point to stable/victoria for:
  - charmhelpers
  - charms.openstack (as needed)
  - zaza & zaza.openstack.tests
- Remove unsupported test bundles
- migration bundles to charmhub.io (ch: prefix + channels)
- Build on 20.04 amd64
- Run on 20.04 amd64, s390x, ppc64el, arm64
- Remove .coveragerc
- Pin tempest for python<3.8

Change-Id: Ie0f0cef3e924dfe502e4e72e83a442937aacef7f

commit_message:
Charmhub migration for stable/train (bionic-only)

This is the main patch for the migration of the stable/21.10
charm to charmhub for the stable/train branch (train track on
charmhub).  This patch initially supports bionic from queens
to train, and does not support ussuri.  It supports upgrades
from bionic-queens to bionic-train (with each intermediate
step needed).  Crucially it does NOT set a default
openstack-origin, which means installing train/stable
without specifying the openstack-origin will result in a
bionic-queens installation.  This is intentional as the branch
covers queens to train.

Change-Id: I47574f0ffa58080334ae68b6da128e86eabed041

commit_message:
Migrate charm charmhub for stable/wallaby

- start from stable/wallaby branch
- Do charmcraft, osci, zuul changes
- Modify libs to point to stable/wallaby for:
  - charmhelpers
  - charms.openstack (as needed)
  - zaza & zaza.openstack.tests
- Remove unsupported test bundles
- migration bundles to charmhub.io (ch: prefix + channels)
- Build on 20.04 amd64
- Run on 20.04 amd64, s390x, ppc64el, arm64
- Use tempest<31.0.0 for python<'3.8'

Change-Id: I8490b53a6bf8605836f7ddb8b7184a734ad10fe3

commit_message:
Drop the use of 'crm node status' on jammy.

The version of crmsh available on jammy doesn't have the 'crm node
status' subcommand available since it was removed[0], this change uses
the command 'crm node attribute' to figure out if the node is in standby
mode when running on ubuntu>=jammy, and 'crm node show' to get the list
of nodes.

[0] https://github.com/ClusterLabs/crmsh/pull/753

Change-Id: Iafb711be220573cb701527ec84de285edd8942cf
Closes-Bug: #1972022

subject: Install resource-agents-extra on jammy.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-05-06 13:59:19.000000000', 'files': ['hooks/hooks.py', 'unit_tests/test_hacluster_hooks.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-hacluster/commit/32ab2d4bda69b7dff695ff0170d3c51cecac0b36', 'message': "Install resource-agents-extra on jammy.

The install hooks rsync a set of scripts and one of the destinations
is /usr/lib/stonith/plugins/external, this directory is created by the
installation of the package cluster-glue which is a pulled as an
indirect dependency of pacemaker, this changed on >=jammy where an
intermediate package named resource-agents was split into
resource-agents-base and resource-agents-extra wher the latter doesn't
get installed and it's the one that depends on cluster-glue.

The specific chain of dependencies are:

focal:
pacemaker -> pacemaker-resource-agents -> resource-agents -> cluster-glue

jammy
pacemaker -> pacemaker-resource-agents -> resource-agents-base

Change-Id: Ia00061bff2ebe16d35d52b256c61243935edabba
Closes-Bug: #1971841
"}]
commit_message:
Install resource-agents-extra on jammy.

The install hooks rsync a set of scripts and one of the destinations
is /usr/lib/stonith/plugins/external, this directory is created by the
installation of the package cluster-glue which is a pulled as an
indirect dependency of pacemaker, this changed on >=jammy where an
intermediate package named resource-agents was split into
resource-agents-base and resource-agents-extra wher the latter doesn't
get installed and it's the one that depends on cluster-glue.

The specific chain of dependencies are:

focal:
pacemaker -> pacemaker-resource-agents -> resource-agents -> cluster-glue

jammy
pacemaker -> pacemaker-resource-agents -> resource-agents-base

Change-Id: Ia00061bff2ebe16d35d52b256c61243935edabba
Closes-Bug: #1971841
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-hacluster refs/changes/05/840905/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch.object(hooks, 'get_distrib_codename') filter_installed_packages, mkdir, emit_corosync_conf, get_distrib_codename): get_distrib_codename.return_value = 'focal' apt_install.reset_mock() get_distrib_codename.return_value = 'jammy' apt_install.assert_called_once_with( expected_pkgs + ['resource-agents-extra'], fatal=True)

commit_message:
Fix nested mounts of /run/openvswitch

As kolla-toolbox is mounting /run:/run
there is no need to mount also /run/openvswitch.
This is causing /run/openvswitch is mounted
again and again up to 32767 times after kolla-toolbox
restart.

Closes-Bug: #1979295
Change-Id: I49b3bde8b2bd61b6c931a81542a0d89f8a303ffc
(cherry picked from commit 889c0d168c9cd2f6b49746c4200bcd020eb04642)

subject: CI: Extend timeouts for RAX
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-06-23 16:32:36.000000000', 'files': ['playbooks/integration/exercise.yaml', '.zuul.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/metalsmith/commit/98c4c96c33269e1419e37fc0a5c2979ff7c1c101', 'message': 'CI: Extend timeouts for RAX

It appears our jobs end up encountering some performance issues
on some RAX hosts where the overall runtime is already close to
the maximum for the job window.

Ultimately what happens is the performance ends up putting the boot
of the workload VM just a little bit later and we end up failing
the job as the VM is still early in booting up.

Change-Id: I309220d7f61f87b7457668fcf586d4ea152d363b
'}]
commit_message:
CI: Extend timeouts for RAX

It appears our jobs end up encountering some performance issues
on some RAX hosts where the overall runtime is already close to
the maximum for the job window.

Ultimately what happens is the performance ends up putting the boot
of the workload VM just a little bit later and we end up failing
the job as the VM is still early in booting up.

Change-Id: I309220d7f61f87b7457668fcf586d4ea152d363b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/metalsmith refs/changes/80/847380/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
ovs-dpdk: add ovs-dpdkctl.sh to the role itself

Currently the ovs-dpdkctl.sh file is present in the tools
directory and the "Copying ovs-dpdkctl tool" task accesses it.

This is bad practice. Files copied from a role should either be
referenced by an absolute path or be part of the role itself.

This change moves the ovs-dpdkctl.sh file in the files
directory of the role.

Change-Id: I01459d39207e54f270f32f37b4a5153c5a819347
(cherry picked from commit 89659b4607f9a121e9ce6fe8adf82cc212922026)

commit_message:
ovs-dpdk: add ovs-dpdkctl.sh to the role itself

Currently the ovs-dpdkctl.sh file is present in the tools
directory and the "Copying ovs-dpdkctl tool" task accesses it.

This is bad practice. Files copied from a role should either be
referenced by an absolute path or be part of the role itself.

This change moves the ovs-dpdkctl.sh file in the files
directory of the role.

Change-Id: I01459d39207e54f270f32f37b4a5153c5a819347
(cherry picked from commit 89659b4607f9a121e9ce6fe8adf82cc212922026)

commit_message:
Improve kolla-ansible bash completion script

- Do not suggest file or dir names in current dir when action is yet to
  be typed.
- Do not suggest action names if an action was already typed.

Change-Id: If4b167228ba8c297a4fed6eb2348e2c56a940718

added_lines: COMPREPLY=( $(compgen -W "${kolla_ansible_flags}" -- "${cur}") ) # check whether an action was already typed action_specified=0 for word in "${COMP_WORDS[@]}"; do if [ -n "${word}" ] && echo ${kolla_ansible_actions} | tr " " "\n" | grep -E -q -e "^${word}$"; then action_specified=1 break fi done if [[ ${action_specified} == 0 ]]; then COMPREPLY=( $(compgen -W "${kolla_ansible_actions}" -- "${cur}") ) ficomplete -o default -F _kolla_ansible kolla-ansible

commit_message:
Add Keep Alive Timeout for httpd

This patch introduces a global keep alive timeout value for services
that leverage httpd + wsgi to handle http/https requests. The default
value is one minute.

Change-Id: Icf7cb0baf86b428a60a7e9bbed642999711865cd
Partially-Implements: blueprint add-ssl-internal-network
(cherry picked from commit 19b028e660fde34d83311025b5a4a1d4d3d59e2e)

commit_message:
Fix image builds with sources using a type=git

A recent change to git [1] introduced a new behaviour to work around a
CVE [2] that disallows any git operations in directories not owned by
the current user.

This may seem unrelated to installation, but it plays havoc with PBR,
which calls out to git to get to get revision history.  So if you are
"pip install"-ing from a source tree you don't own, the PBR git calls
in that tree now fail and the install blows up.

When using type=source, kolla clones the repository, then creates a
tarball from it, which is ADDed to the image. The ownership of the files
in the tarball is preserved, which in this case will be the user running
kolla-build. Since the Docker build runs as root, we hit the PBR issue.

Our solution is to make sure that any tarball we generate from git
sources have all files owned by root:root so that the root user is able
to use git commands when building container images.

[1] https://github.com/git/git/commit/8959555cee7ec045958f9b6dd62e541affb7e7d9
[2] https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2022-24765.

Closes-Bug: #1969096
Related-Bug: #1968877

Co-Authored-By: Mark Goddard <mark@stackhpc.com>
Change-Id: I2cbf1f539880d512aa223c3ef3a4b19ee18854ac
(cherry picked from commit c4fda7baa3ffc36b555c32a34a00042b6035b917)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/62/846562/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - | Fixes an issue building images that use a source with a ``type`` of ``git``, when using a git that includes the fix for `CVE-2022-24765 <https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2022-24765>`__ (2.35.2 or later). By default, this includes the ``gnocchi-base`` image, but may include other images with a non-default configuration. `LP#837710 <https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla/+/837710>`__

commit_message:
Fix image builds with sources using a type=git

A recent change to git [1] introduced a new behaviour to work around a
CVE [2] that disallows any git operations in directories not owned by
the current user.

This may seem unrelated to installation, but it plays havoc with PBR,
which calls out to git to get to get revision history.  So if you are
"pip install"-ing from a source tree you don't own, the PBR git calls
in that tree now fail and the install blows up.

When using type=source, kolla clones the repository, then creates a
tarball from it, which is ADDed to the image. The ownership of the files
in the tarball is preserved, which in this case will be the user running
kolla-build. Since the Docker build runs as root, we hit the PBR issue.

Our solution is to make sure that any tarball we generate from git
sources have all files owned by root:root so that the root user is able
to use git commands when building container images.

[1] https://github.com/git/git/commit/8959555cee7ec045958f9b6dd62e541affb7e7d9
[2] https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2022-24765.

Closes-Bug: #1969096
Related-Bug: #1968877

Co-Authored-By: Mark Goddard <mark@stackhpc.com>

(cherry picked from commit c4fda7baa3ffc36b555c32a34a00042b6035b917)

commit_message:
CI: Use 2 cpus for IPA jobs

When uncompressing large IPA images, which happens more often in
IPA jobs due to the explicit need to test the larger images, only a
single CPU core being permitted creates a bottleneck for in VM
thread scheduling, which can be observed with initial VM start once
in ram contents begin to become uncompressed.

This should help some things along. Long ago we observed ~30% boot
time speed reduction with this in CI.

Change-Id: If2b3440ea1901e9965f3977d288ba15ebbb06b5e

commit_message:
Fix 'tox -e releasenotes'

Running 'tox -e releasenotes' fails with:

ERROR: You must give at least one requirement to install

Added missing doc/requirements.txt dep to tox.ini

Trivialfix

Change-Id: I174460a0c1f4616cbdcb78bb8682adfe894f4206

commit_message:
[OSC] Add functional tests for share types

Add functional tests for 'openstack share type' commands.

Change-Id: Ib41a517c96d914fade307ae941ab0f38bc21ff0b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-manilaclient refs/changes/55/842855/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def create_share_type(self, name=None, dhss=False, description=None, snapshot_support=None, create_share_from_snapshot_support=None, revert_to_snapshot_support=False, mount_snapshot_support=False, extra_specs={}, public=True, add_cleanup=True, client=None): name = name or data_utils.rand_name('autotest_share_type_name') cmd = (f'create {name} {dhss}') if description: cmd = cmd + f' --description {description}' if snapshot_support: cmd = cmd + f' --snapshot-support {snapshot_support}' if create_share_from_snapshot_support: cmd = cmd + f' create-share-from-snapshot-support \ {create_share_from_snapshot_support}' if revert_to_snapshot_support: cmd = cmd + f' --revert-to-snapshot-support \ {revert_to_snapshot_support}' if mount_snapshot_support: cmd = cmd + f' --mount-snapshot-support {mount_snapshot_support}' share_type = self.dict_result('share type', cmd, client=client) if add_cleanup: self.addCleanup( self.openstack, f'share type delete {share_type["id"]}' ) return share_type

commit_message:
Define queues at project level

Defining queues at project.pipeline level was deprecated in release
4.1.0 of Zuul [1] and support for it will (probably) be dropped in
release 7.0.0. [2][3]

[1] https://zuul-ci.org/docs/zuul/latest/releasenotes.html#relnotes-4-1-0-deprecation-notes
[2] https://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2022-May/028603.html
[3] https://lists.zuul-ci.org/pipermail/zuul-discuss/2022-May/001801.html

Signed-off-by: Eduardo Santos <eduardo.experimental@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Ife023187f307f1190d5e76daf644db0b5cd55d38

commit_message:
Support multiple allocations for vGPUs

Removing the TODO that only allows one VGPU allocation per instance. Now we no
longer need to support the very old VGPU usage for the root provider, this
is easy.

Change-Id: I48d2b700049c81071710e37c05579239255c3539
Related-Bug: #1758086
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/57/845757/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: chosen_mdevs = [] for rp_uuid, alloc in vgpu_allocations.items(): # We only have one allocation with a supported resource class vgpus_asked = list(alloc['resources'].values())[0] try: allocated_rp = self.provider_tree.data(rp_uuid) except ValueError: # The provider doesn't exist, return a better understandable # exception raise exception.ComputeResourcesUnavailable( reason='mdev-capable resource is not available') supported_types = self.supported_vgpu_types # Which mediated devices are created but not assigned to a guest ? mdevs_available = self._get_existing_mdevs_not_assigned( parent_device, supported_types) for c in range(vgpus_asked): chosen_mdev = None if mdevs_available: # Take the first available mdev chosen_mdev = mdevs_available.pop() else: chosen_mdev = self._create_new_mediated_device( parent_device) if not chosen_mdev: # If we can't find devices having available VGPUs, just # raise raise exception.ComputeResourcesUnavailable( reason='mdev-capable resource is not available') else: chosen_mdevs.append(chosen_mdev)
deleted_lines: # TODO(sbauza): For the moment, we only support allocations for only # one pGPU. if len(vgpu_allocations) > 1: LOG.warning('More than one allocation was passed over to libvirt ' 'while at the moment libvirt only supports one. Only ' 'the first allocation will be looked up.') rp_uuid, alloc = next(iter(vgpu_allocations.items())) # We only have one allocation with a supported resource class vgpus_asked = list(alloc['resources'].values())[0] # Find if we allocated against a specific pGPU (and then the allocation # is made against a child RP) or any pGPU (in case the VGPU inventory # is still on the root RP) try: allocated_rp = self.provider_tree.data(rp_uuid) except ValueError: # The provider doesn't exist, return a better understandable # exception raise exception.ComputeResourcesUnavailable( reason='mdev-capable resource is not available') # FIXME(sbauza): The functional reshape test assumes that we could # run _allocate_mdevs() against non-nested RPs but this is impossible # as all inventories have been reshaped *before now* since it's done # on init_host() (when the compute restarts or whatever else calls it). # That said, since fixing the functional test isn't easy yet, let's # assume we still support a non-nested RP for now. if allocated_rp.parent_uuid is None: # We are on a root RP parent_device = None else: supported_types = self.supported_vgpu_types # Which mediated devices are created but not assigned to a guest ? mdevs_available = self._get_existing_mdevs_not_assigned( parent_device, supported_types) chosen_mdevs = [] for c in range(vgpus_asked): chosen_mdev = None if mdevs_available: # Take the first available mdev chosen_mdev = mdevs_available.pop() else: chosen_mdev = self._create_new_mediated_device(parent_device) if not chosen_mdev: # If we can't find devices having available VGPUs, just raise raise exception.ComputeResourcesUnavailable( reason='mdev-capable resource is not available') else: chosen_mdevs.append(chosen_mdev)
